{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3243127,"name":"Rufus Mainwaring","username":"Rufus_t_Doofus","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rufus_t_doofus/{size}/179852_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-20T03:26:37.737Z","cooked":"

Hi there CD,

847 is looking to transition a majority of building marterials over to ION, and is wondering with a $1,000 budget (doesn’t need to be reached), what it might make sense to purchase. 847 is still relatively green in the design department, so we aren’t going to be generating the most complex robots. I have a pretty good idea of what to get, but I know I am not super knowledgeable in this area (I will also definitely forget the obvious stuff). Here are some things that
we are currently considering:

  • Additional Maxtube (currently have 3 max-length pieces besides swerve-dt).
  • Maxspline (I don’t expect this to be a go-to inseason for lack of experience with dead-axles)
  • 10 Gussets and Brackets (not sure what types besides L’s and T’s)
  • More hex shaft
  • Maxplanetary (not sure what ratios/how many)
  • Thrifty elevator kit? (if not then some bearing blocks at least)
  • Encoders of some sort? (we’ve used ultraplanetary encoders most recently, and I’m not sure what our best through bore options are).

I’d love feedback on anything I’m missing/should maybe change. 847 Hasn’t been super up-to-date with modern FRC components in a while (especially since the pandemic). I thought I’d also clarrify that we are fairly up-to date mostly motor wise, and it’s a simple enough part category that I’m on top of it .

Thank you for reading,

Rufus ~ 847 PHRED A/M

-For the amount of maxtube you need, why not just look at the CAD for a few robots and see how much maxtube people used. You probably want thick walled for drive train and thin for everything else, that worked well for 112 last year. 112 used 163 inches of maxtube not on our drivetrain from looking at the CAD.
-maxspline can be good but probably not the most important thing to spend money on.
-L and T brackets seem like a really good thing to get if you don’t have a router
-Hex shaft is good
-It’s hard to know how many maxplanetaries you need without knowing the game and the general robot archetecture. Maxplanetaries are really good though, I’d recommend getting some. Really, almost all the ratios you can do are really useful until you get to really high gear ratios so multiple 60:1s would probably be great
-Elevator kit might be better to wait until you know the game and know if you need an elevator.
-Through bore encoders from rev have worked pretty well for us as far as I know, you might want to look into Redux Canandcoder for a cheaper option that I haven’t heard anything bad about.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2023-10-20T03:55:25.361Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":255,"readers_count":254,"score":126.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":442773,"topic_slug":"getting-started-with-ion","display_username":"Eliot Dunn","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://shop.reduxrobotics.com/helium-canandcoder/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"HELIUM Canandcoder","clicks":5}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52966,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"111 Alum"},"post_url":"/t/getting-started-with-ion/442773/2","custom_user_title":"111 Alum","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3243136,"name":"AllenGregoryIV","username":"AllenGregoryIV","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/allengregoryiv/{size}/65531_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-20T04:23:59.582Z","cooked":"

Some suggestions

  • tube end caps are some of our favorite ION parts we used dozens of them on our robot in 2023. Both the 11 and both versions of the 21.
  • Max 90 gearbox, we love these now. Our off-season had 3 running the elevator slide, shoulder, and elbow.
  • the “MaxSpline Brackets” (REV-21-2353) can be useful for connection 2*1s on their wide face
  • 25 chain, sprockets (48t is our favorite), and the chain turnbuckles
  • 10-32 standoffs stock (3/8" 6061 rounded hex that can be tapped to 10-32) is very useful, part number REV-21-2076
  • If you’re going to buy the ION wheels you should also buy the MaxHubs, these can be 3D printed in some applications.
  • As for MaxSpline shaft itself it works very well for arms/wrists when paired with some bushing from McMaster. We also used it with snap rings and cut grooves in it on our lathe and this worked great.
Rufus_t_Doofus:

Thrifty elevator kit?

  • the hole pattern on the thrifty elevator blocks don’t align with the REV ION pattern, however the WCP inline (I think that the right name, but the ones that look like the thrifty blocks) do align. We made our alpha elevator using the thrifty blocks and moved to the WCP blocks so we wouldn’t have to drill new holes in the tube.

  • as for encoders, we have just relied on the internal encoder of the brushless motors for most things and have been happy. Some things could use the REV thru-bore encoder but many applications don’t need it if you can zero the mechanism reliably.

AllenGregoryIV:

as for encoders, we have just relied on the internal encoder of the brushless motors for most things and have been happy.

Ahh yes, there’s both my lack of experience and my forgetfulness kicking in .

We’ve generally used otherwise wasted churro stock for standoffs, I guess the main advantage of 3/8" is woukd mostly be space savings?

Thanks for all the help!

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2023-10-20T15:46:17.444Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":133,"readers_count":132,"score":41.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":442773,"topic_slug":"getting-started-with-ion","display_username":"Rufus Mainwaring","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53720,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"847 Alumnus/Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/getting-started-with-ion/442773/4","custom_user_title":"847 Alumnus/Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3243283,"name":"AllenGregoryIV","username":"AllenGregoryIV","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/allengregoryiv/{size}/65531_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-20T16:06:14.332Z","cooked":"
Rufus_t_Doofus:

We’ve generally used otherwise wasted churro stock for standoffs, I guess the main advantage of 3/8" is would mostly be space savings?

The biggest advantage is keeping everything 10-32. Standard 1/2" churro has a 0.23 thru hole so it can only be tapped to 1/4-20 and we try to avoid different size bolts on the robot if we can avoid it.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2023-10-20T16:06:14.332Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":116,"readers_count":115,"score":28.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":442773,"topic_slug":"getting-started-with-ion","display_username":"AllenGregoryIV","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":10647,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Engineering Coach - Spectrum 3847/Photon 8515"},"post_url":"/t/getting-started-with-ion/442773/5","custom_user_title":"Engineering Coach - Spectrum 3847/Photon 8515","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3243284,"name":"Rufus Mainwaring","username":"Rufus_t_Doofus","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rufus_t_doofus/{size}/179852_2.png","created_at":"2023-10-20T16:08:52.820Z","cooked":"

Of course! So used to 1/4" that I didn’t even think of the hole size in specifically churros.

Thank you

Just noticed that there are two types of 2x1 endcaps, what are the different use-cases for them?

Edit: nevermind, I figured it out (for the different wall thicknesses of tubes)
